5-Axis Robotic Arm WIP

Study project — learning robotics through real mechanical design, cycloidal drive experiments and motion tests.

Why I’m building this

I’m building this 5-axis robotic arm as a hands-on study project to get closer to robotics and automation in a concrete way. Instead of learning only from theory, I’m using real mechanical design, prototyping and motion tests to understand:

  • mechanical transmissions (cycloidal drives, tolerances, backlash)
  • structural rigidity and repeatable motion
  • multi-axis actuation and control concepts

The goal is not “a perfect industrial robot”, but a compact modular platform that lets me iterate and learn quickly.

1) Concept & Goal

This sketch shows the overall concept of the 5-axis robotic arm. The objective is a compact, modular structure focused on cycloidal drives and reliable, repeatable motion.

Component sketches

Two key components that drive the design of the entire arm: the cycloidal transmission and the shoulder structure. These sketches represent early design reasoning before committing to printed parts.

Cycloidal drive

Sketch exploring geometry, tolerances and assembly of the cycloidal transmission, focusing on smooth motion and backlash reduction.

Shoulder assembly

Structural concept for the shoulder joint, studying load paths, rigidity and motor placement for multi-axis movement.

2) Cycloidal Drive Iterations

Multiple cycloidal gear prototypes printed to test geometry, tolerances and assembly. Each iteration helped refine smoothness, backlash and strength.

3) Cycloidal Movement Test

Close-up test showing only the cycloidal movement, used to evaluate smoothness and mechanical behavior.

4) Current State: Shoulder & Elbow

Current build status showing shoulder and elbow assemblies. The next steps focus on rigidity improvements and integration of the remaining axes.

5) Arm Motion Test

Full arm motion test used to verify joint alignment, movement fluidity and overall mechanical stability.
